The vanilla base game is okay. The shipbuilding is great, and being able to import assets from other games, voxelize them, and drop them right in is genuinely cool. The game sells itself as a sandbox space-combat/light-economy sort of deal—basically an “X4 lite.” But where X4 has a deep, living economy and a world that actually reacts to things (even if it limits your creativity), Avorion is the opposite. You get tons of freedom to build whatever you want, but the world underneath feels pretty shallow. After a few hours you’ve basically seen every sector layout, quests start repeating, combat feels kind of average, and factions mostly just… exist in the background without doing much.

So why a positive review? Simple: the Xavorion mod. Somehow a modder managed to bring out the potential the base game only hints at. The mod adds a real supply-and-demand economy, AI factions that actually compete with you, sectors that finally feel different, and much better faction interaction instead of everyone just sitting there pretending to be alive. It even improves the combat enough to make fights feel more engaging instead of “point, shoot, repeat.”

It’s still not X4-level deep, but it’s a huge step closer—and honestly, this mod basically saved the game for me. Vanilla is just painfully average on its own.

Sometimes developers build the canvas, but modders end up painting the masterpiece.

Avorion is the game I wished No Man's Sky to be. 

I am a big fan of sandbox games, automation games, survival, crafting, and continuous progression games. Avorion offers you the perfect mix of all these types of games. It is a large sandbox with great systems working on top of it. I like the story mode (skipable) of working your way up from nothing. The various difficulties offer the right degree of challenge for everyone. In a way, it is comparable with Mount & Blade. The journey from nobody to fleet commander is the enjoyable and replayable part of this game. 
Have I mentioned the complete freedom you are given in the ship editor? Mining resources to build your perfect spaceship feels so rewarding - and every battle feels engaging as you might lose all the precious goods you just acquired. No save game reload (apart from copying the whole galaxy folder) is possible. 

I have played for about 100 hours now and I have engaged with many of the systems but I have yet to reach the endgame.

I have not touched on the major addition to that: Multiplayer & Workshop
This will certainly increase the replayability by a ton.

What needs to be improved?
Sometimes travel feels slow (due to loading between each tile on the map). But you can work your way around that with a larger ship, system slots or hyperspace cores.
The game could also benefit from some quest variety - even if they are generic. The simple fetch quests for example could certainly benefit to make the early game more engaging.

The price point of this game is fair. You can argue about the DLCs but I think the complete package is worth the money.

Have you ever been playing Space Engineers and thought to yourself "man, I wish this looked more like Minecraft and felt like Eve Online"? Good news, go buy this.

This is a really cool game. It takes the trading/fighting/exploration of a game like Elite: Dangerous or the X games, adds in the building of Minecraft (or From the Depths. It's an easier to deal with version of From the Depths, set in space and with an economic system, if that means anything to you), and then out of nowhere, tacks on the ability to turn the whole thing into an RTS that you play entirely from a map.

Besides the building, it doesn't do any of these things *quite* as well as other games, likely in no small part because it's still in Beta. Automated combat doesn't work super super well, but it's passable. It doesn't look as good as non-voxel games, but it still looks nice. But it does everything well enough that you still enjoy playing it, and you're pretty free to entirely ignore portions of the game if you'd like. It's easier to set up bases and mining fleets and whatever, but I'm absolutely sure a person could play through the game as a single ship too.

I haven't played around with mods yet, but it's easy to tell that this game takes well to them, and there's already a few popular ones out there.

The story is... i actually have no idea. Probably badly written and translated from another language, as is usually the case with these games. I *genuinely* have no idea though - I play games like Disco Elysium to pay attention to a story. I play 4x/open world/freeform RPG type games to play the game. It's something about aliens at the center of the galaxy doing badguy stuff, or something, I think. The first thing I did was skip the tutorial/story intro and fly off into a rock.

Beyond that, you get a pile of procgen factions with various traits to make your own stories up with, be it because you're a nice guy who has helped them out and founded alliances, or because you've turned them into historical footnotes by killing them all and subsuming their empires. Or, you can just completely ignore them and fly around a fight pirates, or be a pirate, on your own. It's not really a game that gives you much for specific goals beyond "go here, find this, kill that, get to the center of the galaxy", which you will either love, or completely bounce off of.

Coolest part: Just the fact that I can build my own ship of whatever designed I want to put the time into, arm it with weapons I design the appearance of, and then direct it to rendevous with a dozen ships like it in a sector containing asteroid mines and a huge variety of factory space stations, all of which I can also design if I want. Then I can send them off to fight someone on the other side of the map while I do something else, but still hop into one of them when they get there and kick some ass myself. Or I can hop into a fighter launched by one of them (which I've also designed) and be actually a little blown away by the scale of everything while I make an attack run on an enemy ship I've just realized is almost the size of the valley I live in in real life.

Least cool part: I have to manually load out every single ship I build, the AI that operates my ships isn't very good (enemies are fine), and in general, the RTS elements are quite there yet. They are better than in From the Depths or any other game like this I can think of, but there's still a little ways to go before your faction's AI-controlled ships perform like the AI ships. Or at least that's what it feels like. 

But as an example, if you set your flagship to have autoturrets on it (so you don't have to aim and fire them and can focus on big guns or flying), they will only fire if they are all on roughly the same plane and have the same arcs/lines of fire within their fire control group. This is fine on AI designs, where they are all mounted this way, but *you* probably won't want to mount them that way. This means a ship that you, as the player, can absolutely crush stuff in will usually be firing only a fraction of it's guns when the AI uses it, as the same AI that runs the autofire system appears to run the overall combat system.

It's not a game breaker, but it does sort of pull you out of the immersion and is just... dissapointing, I guess, relative to how well everything else seems to work in the game. This is compounded by the fact that the game is in a schroedinger box - when you don't observe the action (i.e. watch a fight, idle in the same sector as your mines, etc.), a lot of stuff behaves differently than if you do - it appears to be abstracted at that point. Which isn't at all unusual for a game, but feels like it stands out a bit specifically when it comes to the combat here. The economy works similarly but feels more "normal".

Honestly, this game is a bit of a maybe for me.

On one hand, the editor is quite potent. It is a bit of a learning curve to figure out the editor, the UI is not at all intuitive. But, once you do figure out the editor, it is very functional. You can design ships. You can design stations. And with the shapes and scaling tools available the only real limitation here is your imagination and patience. Check out the workshop if you're curious about that. People have made some truly gorgeous ships in this game.

On the other hand, the game play itself is fairly basic. Making a strong ship mostly boils down to more guns, more shields, enough thrust and maneuverability to move well, and a big enough reactor to make that all work smoothly. With enough firepower and shields, most things stop being a threat quite quickly. Ship design itself, from a functional standpoint, is quite basic. Everything is a scaleable solid. Engines, reactors, engines, armor, it's all just boxes of various shapes you can snap together. 

You can have a fleet. Mostly this just means sending ships out to do something for some amount of time and return with the profits. You can assign a ship to be your wingman if you wish too. You can design stations. Stations are expensive, but they provide steady passive income and other handy features once you get that set up. 

And there a galaxy to explore, but it's procedural and mostly feels the same. Closer to the center things do get harder. There's a progression of 7 different materials. Iron and Titanium to start at the fringe where you start. Ending in the titular metal Avorion as you reach the center of the galaxy. Mostly, this just means you build stuff in the highest material you've got to make everything stronger.

So in the end, I think this game boils down to a simple question. Do you want to design pretty ships? Or do you just want to  play a game and explore? If you are a designer, this game is a solid choice for it. If you aren't . . . maybe give this one a pass.

Avorion - An Overhyped Space Mess with Missed Potential

I really wanted to like Avorion. The premise sounded amazing: an expansive, dynamic space sandbox where I could design my own ships, blast through enemies with tons of turrets, and maybe even build a vast space empire. The freedom of ship design is a huge hook, and the chaos of firing a thousand bullets at once is undeniably satisfying. But after putting in far too many hours, it's clear: Avorion is a game that has no idea what it wants to be, and it's maddening to watch it squander its potential.

Let's talk about the major issue here: the developers. They clearly have no direction. The game constantly feels like it's in an identity crisis. Are they making an open-world, action-oriented single-ship space game? Or are they aiming for a more complex, X4 style space empire simulator? The answer is neither, and unfortunately, the game is trying to do both while failing at both.

Automation—one of the key aspects I was really excited for is frustratingly broken. Your ships will not defend themselves unless you set them to a specific combat mission. That's the only way they'll engage enemies. Which, by the way, means they can’t do anything else if they're in “attack mode.” So much for having automated fleets of ships helping you out while you focus on other things. If you're thinking that maybe you can automate some production or factory work to make your empire run smoothly, think again. The game doesn't even let you control factory inputs, meaning your stations will get choked up with a single resource and grind to a halt. Want to send a freighter off to sell some materials manually and clear up space for production? Too bad. Docking bugs make that impossible.

It’s just downright broken. I had issues that had been reported for years, and when I looked into it, the devs have essentially shrugged and admitted they're not fixing them. It’s like they’ve given up on ironing out the kinks while they’ve been focusing on adding more features that don’t really solve anything.

I gave Avorion the best shot I could. There’s so much here that could be great if only the devs would pick a direction and stick with it. Right now, it feels like you’re playing a half-baked idea that can’t make up its mind between a solo action experience or an empire-building simulation. Until they decide, this is a game that will remain a frustrating, buggy mess.

Avorion isn't bad because it’s unfinished; it’s bad because the developers are trying to do too much at once and not succeeding in any meaningful way. Until they fix the broken systems and actually commit to one vision, I can't recommend it.

Are they making an open-world, action-oriented single-ship space game? Or are they aiming for a more complex, X4 style space empire simulator? The answer is neither, and unfortunately, the game is trying to do both while failing at both.

That's the only way they'll engage enemies. Which, by the way, means they can’t do anything else if they're in “attack mode.” So much for having automated fleets of ships helping you out while you focus on other things. If you're thinking that maybe you can automate some production or factory work to make your empire run smoothly, think again. The game doesn't even let you control factory inputs, meaning your stations will get choked up with a single resource and grind to a halt. Want to send a freighter off to sell some materials manually and clear up space for production? Too bad. Docking bugs make that impossible.

Avorion is a game I'd recommend if you REALLY like building, or if you have a lot of patience. Or if, like me, you like doing something else, but having a game you can check on every half hour or so that mainly just plays itself after a bit of setup.

Does that sound boring? Yeah, it kind of is. Singleplayer and multiplayer want the same thing to finish the game; a decent sized fleet of ships. And yes, more people can gather more, but it also means more ships in general, so the waiting ends up being about the same. And the numbers of resources you need just goes up more and more the further you get in, and the bigger your ships get, so eventually you're spending HOURS waiting for enough of one type to upgrade ONE ship, and then upgrade the next one, to slowly push forward, so you can do it again.

Yes, you could keep yourself occupied fighting pirates and doing missions and whatnot, but it's not as fast as mining, so it still boils down to a crapload of time to get the stuff needed to progress.

Which is fine... up to a point where you just kind of find the whole thing tedious, and just kind of... stop playing.

I've done at least three different multiplayer games of this, and three different singleplayer ones, and the multiplayer ones have all fizzled out for the same reason: people got bored of the same grind.

I've only gotten to the inner ring ONCE, and it's... just not super interesting.

Now, certain mechanics are fun, and there IS some enjoyment to be had. I'll probably start up another singleplayer campaign eventually, and play it in the background a bit, and then get bored and stop for a few months, then repeat. Which I'm okay with. I'm not upset at the money or time spent. 

But if you want a different experience, maybe try a different game.
